title: Mandated vs. Voluntary Adaptation to Natural Disasters: The Case of U.S. Wildfires
text: Baylis, Patrick, and Judson Boomhower. “The economic incidence of wildfire suppression in the United States.” American Economic Journal: Applied Economics 15, no. 1 (2023): 442-473.

title: Mandated vs. Voluntary Adaptation to Natural Disasters: The Case of U.S. Wildfires
text:
Abstract
This study measures the degree to which public expenditures on wildfire protection subsidize development in harm’s way. We use administrative data on firefighting expenditures to measure the causal effect of nearby homes on the amount spent to extinguish wildfires. We use these estimates in an actuarial calculation yielding geographically differentiated expected implicit subsidies for homes across the western United States. The expected net present value of this subsidy can exceed 20 percent of home value, increases with fire hazard, and decreases surprisingly steeply with development density. We discuss potential behavioral responses by individuals and local governments using a simple economic model.

title: The Economic Incidence of Wildfire Suppression in the United States
text: Baylis, Patrick, and Judson Boomhower. “The economic incidence of wildfire suppression in the United States.” American Economic Journal: Applied Economics 15, no. 1 (2023): 442-473.

title: The Economic Incidence of Wildfire Suppression in the United States
text:
Abstract
This study measures the degree to which public expenditures on wildfire protection subsidize development in harm’s way. We use administrative data on firefighting expenditures to measure the causal effect of nearby homes on the amount spent to extinguish wildfires. We use these estimates in an actuarial calculation yielding geographically differentiated expected implicit subsidies for homes across the western United States. We discuss potential behavioral responses by individuals and local governments using a simple economic model.

title: Patrick Baylis
text: Patrick is an assistant professor and environmental economist at the Vancouver School of Economics at the University of British Columbia (UBC). He studies how people respond to environmental threats like climate change, air pollution, and wildfires.

title: Katherine Wagner
text:
Katherine is an Assistant Professor of Economics at the University of British Columbia. Her research focuses primarily on Environmental and Energy Economics and Public Finance. She uses a range of empirical tools to study questions related to environmental externalities, climate change, and natural resources. She is also a Research Affiliate of the CESifo Network.


Links to Katherine’s papers
Personal website

title: Frederik Noack
text: Frederik’s research focuses on the interaction of economic development and the environment. Specifically, he is interested how improved market access and property rights affect rural welfare and natural resources such as forests, fish stocks and biodiversity.

title: Sumeet Gulati
text:
Sumeet’s bio.
Links to Sumeet’s papers.
Sumeet’s contact info.

title: Jonathan Proctor
text: Jonathan develops and applies new methods to empirically estimate anthropogenic impacts on climate and, in turn, on global socio-environmental systems. He’s particularly fascinated by how light, water and temperature jointly determine crop growth and how high resolution imagery can be used to measure socio-environmental conditions.

title: Resource
text:
Other

https://datastudio.google.com/u/0/



R Packages

ROpenSci Universe: The ROpenSci list of packages includes many that facilitate access to interesting datasets.
Programming

skimr: Quick summary statistics.
charlatan: Make fake data, e.g., names.
bibtex: Parse a .bib file. (Might be useful for this website. There are other related packages, e.g., handlr.)
parzer: Parse messy latitudes and longitudes.

Weather

weathercan: R package to get ECCC weather data.
GSODR: One of a few packages for downloading Global Summary of the Day weather data.
rnoaa: Client for many NOAA data sources.
stationaRy: Hourly weather data from around the world.
prism: Access prism data.
Chirps and Chirts: Global reanalysis weather data, 1983-2016.

Disasters

rrricanes: Hurricane data since 1998.

Pollution

epair: Help with parsing various EPA datasets.

Imagery

rsat: Search, download, and process satellite imagery from several free sources.
rnaturalearth: Natural earth imagery for mapping.

Transport

bikedata: Public bicycle data.

Spatial

geonames: Access geonames.org API to get geography names.

title: UBC Environmental Data Science Lab
text: The UBC Environmental Data Science Lab (EDSL) is a collegial research group based out of the University of British Columbia in Vancouver, BC, Canada.

title: UBC Environmental Data Science Lab
text:
Projects
Our projects ask how people impact the environment, how the environment impacts people, and how better policies and healthy markets can improve the interaction of the two. We (do our best to) answer these questions using the tools of applied economics and data science.

title: UBC Environmental Data Science Lab
text:
Mission
The mission of the lab is to provide a community and a shared set of resources for researchers UBC whose work seeks to understand how people and the environment interact.
